audio_caption: The audio clip begins with lively, futuristic electronic music. The music fades and is replaced by a female voice introducing the topic as "Space 2023," promising a look forward at astronomy. Next, a male speaker with an enthusiastic tone says "Welcome back to The Cosmic Companion," identifies himself as James Maynard, and describes the episode as wrapping up season six with a look at Space 2023. He jokes that a massive nuclear explosion will rip the moon from orbit, but is quickly corrected by the female speaker. The man clarifies the show will focus on what's happening in the night sky over the next 12 months, and preview upcoming show content. A sound effect similar to a camera shutter concludes the segment.

An enthusiastic male speaker introduces a show. He mentions a 3D environment simulating future beyond Earth, space predators and animal hunters on Earth and then the show's guest, shark week regular Paul DeGelder. There is then a change in tone to a slightly more serious one, as the speaker announces a discussion on the history of diversity in space exploration from the earliest days to the modern age, along with the name of the author who will be featured. The episode will be released on January 28th.

The audio clip begins with a male voice announcing the topic of a new look at remastered images from the Apollo project. The speaker names an upcoming guest, NASA expert and historian Andy Saunders, and mentions he will discuss his new work, "Apollo Remastered". Then, a brief clip of a musical interlude plays featuring a bluesy, somewhat melancholic tune, likely played on a slide guitar.

A man speaks, initially in disbelief, about seeing a clear image of Neil Armstrong on the moon. He emphasizes the image's clarity and the impact it had. He then discusses the front cover of something, describing it as a bit of everything and noting it was underexposed and almost unseen. He concludes by calling it an incredible, atmospheric portrait.

The audio clip features a male speaker who is enthusiastic as he describes "the only photograph of an Apollo astronaut in the full suit and bubble helmet in the lunar module". He says, "It's a historic moment, because he's actually looking up through the docking window, undertaking the first ever docking in space between two crude spacecraft." He quotes Rusty Schweikart as saying "I can't tell you how hard he's concentrating in that moment", adding that this was the first time they had ever undertaken the docking. He continues that the controls were set up for landing on the moon, so he was translating through 90 degrees all of those movements. He concludes by saying that they were in a spacecraft that couldn't get them home; it had no heat shield.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker, sounding calm and serious, discussing the consequences of a failed docking maneuver. He says if they didn't dock to the command module that had the heat shield, "they're in trouble." He describes it as "high pressure," "historic moment," requiring "concentrating hard," and also being a "cinematic atmospheric portrait." The speaker expresses that it has "a bit of everything in it." He says this is why it's on the front cover.

The clip begins with a male speaker enthusiastically inviting listeners to watch an interview "starting on fourth of February," focusing on the future on the moon. The speaker then moves to other astronomical events in 2023, including "the usual angular solar... usual angular meteor showers," followed by a slightly exaggerated, theatrical pronouncement that the moon will always be there unless "a giant nuclear explosion!" This leads to a more measured outlook on the year in the night sky, including mentioning a hybrid solar eclipse in April, explaining, "These events appear total in some areas and partial in others, hence the name hybrid." The male speaker adds in a light-hearted manner, "No, they don't run on batteries half the time."

The clip begins with a male speaker in a factual, conversational tone, describing the upcoming eclipse starting in the Southern Indian Ocean and stretching towards Western Australia and Indonesia. He then mentions that people on the islands of Indonesia and parts of Australia will see a partial eclipse. When asked about the kangaroos, the same speaker jokes that "naturally the kangaroos are going to enjoy it as well". This is followed by a short, musical sting that has an uncertain, mysterious mood.

The clip begins with a male speaker announcing a penumbral lunar eclipse in a factual tone, mentioning its visibility in parts of Eastern Europe, Africa, and Asia. This is followed by a female speaker responding with an affirming expression of interest, possibly Australian-accented, before the male speaker returns, stating that the moon is coming closer to Earth, warning of potential nuclear explosion events. Finally, the male speaker concludes by introducing a supermoon in July and another one in August.

The clip starts with a single male speaker delivering astronomical news with a calm, informational tone. He discusses a solar eclipse occurring near Canada and stretching into South America, followed by a partial lunar eclipse visible in Europe, Asia, Africa, and parts of Australia. The speaker specifically mentions the date of the lunar eclipse coinciding with Halloween weekend, after which he lets out a spooky "Ooooo" ghost sound effect.

The clip begins with a solo male speaker advertising a podcast called "Pale Blue Pod," which focuses on space and astronomy. He states it's hosted by an astrophysicist/folklorist and a comedian/space educator, emphasizing that they bring science to everyone with fun, light-hearted episodes. The speaker then provides credentials and backgrounds for the hosts, using a relatively upbeat and informative tone. At the end, he summarizes the podcast and says where to find it. A gentle, space-themed musical interlude plays in the background, setting a reflective, futuristic tone.

The clip begins with a male voice excitedly announcing the guest for the next show, Tony Talato, host of the sci-fi talk podcast. The speaker promises a discussion about the future in space through Metaverse and 3D environments, emphasizing enjoyment of the universe and inviting listeners to tune in. Following this, a female voice speaks in a refined British accent, agreeing enthusiastically. A male voice then concludes with a general welcome and holiday wishes. An upbeat funk instrumental follows, featuring driving bass guitar, drums, and prominent electric guitar, creating an energetic mood.
